text: 1 Chronicles begins with a long section primarily focused on what?
verseText: [Chapters 1-9 contain extensive genealogical lists tracing lineage from Adam.]

text: Who was anointed king over all Israel after Saul's death, according to 1 Chronicles 11?
verseText: Then all Israel gathered together to David at Hebron and said, 'Behold, we are your bone and flesh.'

text: In 1 Chronicles 2:3, who is listed as the first son of Judah?
verseText: The sons of Judah: Er, Onan, and Shelah; these three the wife of Er bore to him, and Er, Judah’s firstborn, was wicked in the sight of the LORD.

text: What city did David capture from the Jebusites and make his capital?
verseText: David and all Israel went to Jerusalem (that is, Jebus)… and David took the stronghold of Zion.

text: Who alone could carry the ark of the covenant according to David’s regulations?
verseText: David said, 'No one but the Levites may carry the ark of God, for the LORD chose them to carry the ark of the LORD and to minister before him forever.'

text: Who joined David’s mighty men by drawing water for him from the well of Bethlehem?
verseText: Abishai… drew water for David from the well of Bethlehem, though the troops were encamped at the stronghold.

text: Which tribe was assigned to keep watch at the gates of the tabernacle?
verseText: But the Levites were officers and judges, officials every matter related to God, and they assisted the people of Israel in the law of God.

text: Who was described as 'the chief of the Levites' in 1 Chronicles 23?
verseText: When David was old… he made Solomon his son king… and gathered the leaders of Israel, the priests and the Levites.

text: Which family among the Levites was in charge of singing?
verseText: The sons of Asaph were Asaph, Zachariah,… and their descendants: 128,000 to give thanks to the LORD.

text: Which son of David was appointed to prepare food before the ark?
verseText: He appointed some of the Levites to minister before the ark of the LORD, to invoke, to give thanks, and to praise the LORD, the God of Israel.

text: Who was the third son of Jesse according to the genealogy in 1 Chronicles?
verseText: Abinadab… Shimea the third.

text: Who carried the ark of God with levers on their shoulders?
verseText: The Levites carried the ark of God on their shoulders with the poles, as Moses commanded.

text: Who did David bless in the name of the LORD in 1 Chronicles 29?
verseText: David praised the LORD in the presence of all the assembly, saying, 'Blessed are You, O LORD, the God of Israel our father…'

text: Which man was chosen as the first priest after the ark was moved to Jerusalem?
verseText: And he left Zadok the priest before the tabernacle of the LORD at Gibeon.

text: Which tribe gave 100,000 foot soldiers and 28,000 cavalry to David’s army?
verseText: These were the men who came to David at Ziklag, while he was still hiding… Benjamites: 1,800 men.

text: Who invited David to eat bread in their home when he was fleeing Saul?
verseText: Jonathan and Saul, his father, were sitting under a pomegranate tree at Migron.

text: Who officiated as gatekeepers in Jerusalem?
verseText: Shallum, Akkub, and Talmon were gatekeepers.

text: What did David do before God’s people when he blessed them in 1 Chronicles 29?
verseText: Then David blessed the assembly in the name of the LORD, and day by day they offered to the LORD.

text: Who was appointed to oversee the work on the temple gates?
verseText: Mattithiah the son of Micah… were in charge of the oversight of the gates of the camp.

text: Which descendant of Levi was in charge of the treasuries of the house of God?
verseText: All these were under the hand of Shebuel the son of Gershom, the son of Moses.

text: Which son of Asaph was the father of Heman the singer?
verseText: Ethan the son of Kishi, the son of Abdi, the son of Malluchi, the son of Mazharioth;

text: What instrument did the sons of Heman play?
verseText: And shekels of silver… for cymbals, lyres, and harps.

text: Who was the father of King Asa, listed in the genealogy?
verseText: And Jehoshaphat his son… Jehoram his son… Ahaziah his son… Jehoash his son… Amaziah his son… Uzziah his son… Jotham his son… Ahaz his son… Hezekiah his son… Manasseh his son… Amon his son… Josiah his son… Jehoiachin his son.

text: Who was the first to carry the ark into the tent David had prepared?
verseText: So David… and the priests and the Levites, and all Israel, brought up the ark of the covenant of the LORD with shouting.

text: Which son of Korah is named among temple musicians?
verseText: Their brothers the Korahites… who were among those appointed to give thanks at the house of the LORD.

text: Who did David set over the rooms and treasuries of the house of God?
verseText: Azmaveth the son of Adiel was over the treasuries.

text: What theme does David emphasize in his prayer recorded in 1 Chronicles 17?
verseText: Then David the king went in and sat before the LORD and said, 'Who am I, O Lord GOD, and what is my house, that you have brought me thus far...'

text: Why does David assign the Levites to specific temple duties in 1 Chronicles 23?
verseText: He set apart the sons of Aaron and the Levites to minister before the priests...

text: In 1 Chronicles 21:1, what motive is attributed to Satan in inciting David to number Israel?
verseText: Satan stood up against Israel and incited David to number Israel.

text: What is the significance of the foreign warriors joining David at Ziklag in 1 Chronicles 12?
verseText: All these men of war who could keep rank under the commander of the army...

text: How does 1 Chronicles 16 portray corporate worship under David?
verseText: He appointed some of the Levites to minister before the ark of the LORD, to invoke, to give thanks, and to praise the LORD...

text: What organizational principle underlies the gatekeepers’ assignments in 1 Chronicles 26?
verseText: Moreover David and the officials made the sons of the Korahites and of the Merarites the gatekeepers...

text: What personal quality does David encourage Solomon to exhibit in 1 Chronicles 28:20?
verseText: Be strong and courageous; do not be afraid or discouraged...

text: What was David’s reaction when he realized his census displeased God in 1 Chronicles 21:8?
verseText: And David said to God, 'I have sinned greatly... I have done the very thing I should not have done.'

text: What motivated David to collect materials for the temple in 1 Chronicles 22:5?
options: His wish to build a palace
verseText: And David said, 'Solomon my son is young and inexperienced... I will now make preparation for him.'

text: What role did the descendants of Asaph serve according to 1 Chronicles 25:1?
verseText: David and the commanders of the army set apart some of the sons of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun...

text: What does the gathering at Hebron in 1 Chronicles 12 reveal about Israel’s tribal loyalty?
verseText: They came to Hebron to turn the kingdom of Saul to David...

text: Why did Uzzah touch the ark in 1 Chronicles 13:9-10, despite the prohibition?
verseText: And when they came to Nachon’s threshing floor, Uzzah put out his hand to the ark because the oxen stumbled.

text: David’s decision to move the ark in 1 Chronicles 13 indicates what about his leadership?
verseText: Then David consulted with the commanders of thousands and hundreds...

text: What theological point is underscored by the account of Philistine giants in 1 Chronicles 20:8?
verseText: And in another battle, Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph, who was of the children of the giant.

text: What principle guided the division of priests into 24 courses in 1 Chronicles 24:3?
verseText: So David, with Zadok and Ahimelech, divided them into divisions.

text: How were the porters chosen in 1 Chronicles 26:4-5?
verseText: The porters were chosen by their clans at the king’s command.

text: What does David’s organization of the tribes under captains in 1 Chronicles 27 reflect?
verseText: All these were appointed by name under the authority of King David for the service of the regular forces.

text: In David’s final speech (1 Chronicles 29:10-12), which attribute of God is most emphasized?
verseText: 'Yours, O LORD, is the greatness and the power and the glory... for everything in heaven and earth is yours.'

text: Why does David insist on voluntary contributions in 1 Chronicles 29:5?
verseText: Then the people rejoiced because they had given willingly.

text: How does God’s promise to establish David’s house in 1 Chronicles 17:11-14 shape Israel’s monarchy theology?
verseText: 'When your days are fulfilled... I will raise up your offspring after you and establish his kingdom forever.'

text: What does David’s purchase of Araunah’s threshing floor in 1 Chronicles 21:22 signify?
verseText: David said to Araunah, 'No, but I will buy it from you for a price...' and build an altar.

text: What does the song in 1 Chronicles 16:34 primarily celebrate?
verseText: 'O give thanks to the LORD, for he is good; for his steadfast love endures forever.'

text: How does the listing of David’s mighty warriors in 1 Chronicles 11:10-47 serve the narrative?
options: It highlights God’s empowerment of the humble
verseText: And these are the numbers of the mighty men whom David had:...

text: Why did David appoint Heman and Jeduthun along with Asaph in 1 Chronicles 16:41-42?
verseText: With them Heman and Jeduthun and the rest of those chosen...

text: Which aspect of temple planning in 1 Chronicles 22:14-16 reveals David’s trust in God?
verseText: Behold, with a freewill heart I have offered all these things...

text: What does the monthly tribal assignment in 1 Chronicles 27 reflect about David’s rule?
verseText: All these were in their divisions for the service of the king’s house...

text: How does the narrative in 1 Chronicles 11:6 about Joab’s boldness drive the story forward?
options: Demonstrates loyalty crucial to regaining Jerusalem
verseText: ...Joab… climbed up the water shaft and attacked the city.

text: What organizing principle underlies the division of temple service roles in 1 Chronicles 28:12?
verseText: He put in the hand of his son the plans of the temple...

text: What does the presenting of shields and spears to David in 1 Chronicles 12:18 symbolize?
verseText: And all the rest came under the command of Joab.

text: What was the outcome of placing the ark in Obed-Edom’s house in 1 Chronicles 13:13?
verseText: And the LORD blessed the house of Obed-Edom...

text: What is the significance of the plague on Israel in 1 Chronicles 21:14?
verseText: And God sent the pestilence upon Israel, and 70,000 men fell.

text: What does David’s charge to Solomon in 1 Chronicles 22:13 tell us about David’s self-view?
options: He feels unfit as temple builder
He sees himself as the chief architect
He views himself as a military leader only
verseText: Behold, a son shall be born to you who shall be a man of rest...

text: Why does David emphasize the number of descendants in 1 Chronicles 25:8?
options: To show an abundance of worshipers
verseText: Of them, men of war, 288, able to play instruments...

text: What does the distribution of treasuries in 1 Chronicles 26:20 indicate about David’s governance?
verseText: All these were under the hand of Shebuel the son of Gershom...

text: How does David’s prayer in 1 Chronicles 29:11-12 blend confession and praise?
options: By acknowledging God’s holiness before requesting favor
verseText: 'Yours, O LORD, is the greatness...' and he says, 'And now, our God, we thank you...'

text: What attitude toward wealth is reflected in 1 Chronicles 29:14?
options: Wealth is a gift to return
verseText: For all things come from you, and of your own have we given you.

text: What does the description of Benjamites in 1 Chronicles 12:2 suggest about their character?
verseText: From Benjamin… fearless warriors waiting on David...

text: Why were gatekeepers from the Korahite clan assigned in 1 Chronicles 9:19?
verseText: Shallum, Akkub, and Talmon... were gatekeepers.

text: What significance does Shimei’s shift in allegiance in 1 Chronicles 12:28 carry?
options: It shows tribal readiness for battle
verseText: Then Shimei of the Benjamites... became David’s followers.

text: What narrative function does the emphasis on 'the three mighty men' led by Jashobeam serve in 1 Chronicles 11:14–19?
options: Highlights the elite valor sustaining David’s rise
verseText: [Jashobeam the Hakmonite, chief of the three mighty men, struck down three hundred men at one time.]

text: In 1 Chronicles 12:32, the phrase 'men of Issachar, who understood the times' functions to underscore what deeper point?
options: The importance of discerning divine purposes in political shifts
The musical leadership of the Levites
A scribal gloss inserted by later editors
verseText: [Of Issachar, men who understood the times, with knowledge of what Israel should do.]

text: What political implication is conveyed by including Caleb’s descendants among Judah’s genealogies in 1 Chronicles 2:42–55?
options: Affirmation of Calebite influence within southern Judah
verseText: [These are the sons of Caleb the son of Hezron… his descendants through Jerahmeel, Ram, and Caleb.]

text: How do the temple‑building materials listed in 1 Chronicles 22:14–16 foreshadow Solomon’s architectural program?
options: They prefigure the scale and richness of Solomon’s temple
They reflect David’s personal wealth only
verseText: [Behold, with a freewill heart I have offered all these things… gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, onyx stones, stones for setting.]

text: What rhetorical structure in David’s covenant prayer in 1 Chronicles 17:3–15 exemplifies a chiasm, and to what theological end?
options: The central promise of an enduring dynasty framed by divine initiative
A parallel listing of the northern and southern tribes
A repetitive refrain on temple dimensions
verseText: [When your days are fulfilled and you lie with your fathers, I will raise up your offspring after you… I will be to him a father, and he shall be to me a son.]

text: Why does David’s division of priests into 24 courses in 1 Chronicles 24:3–19 represent more than administrative convenience?
options: It encodes an equitable, covenantal order for cultic service
verseText: [David, with Zadok and Ahimelech, divided them according to their ancestral houses by lot… twenty-four divisions of priests.]

text: What symbolic resonance does the number 288 have in the assignment of temple musicians in 1 Chronicles 25:7–8?
options: It suggests completeness in worship and cosmic harmony
It corresponds to the 288 Levite towns
It denotes days in the liturgical calendar
It marks a boundary of tribal land
verseText: [Of the sons of Asaph… 128,000 to give thanks, 288 of them were designated by name.]

text: How does the inclusion of David’s personal scribe, and the preservation of royal records in 1 Chronicles 29:29–30, function theologically?
options: It legitimizes David’s reign through divine‑sanctioned historiography
verseText: [The records of Samuel… the records of Nathan the prophet, and the records of Gad the seer, are written in the words of the annals of the kings.]

text: What deeper ritual meaning lies in the detailed showbread table plans given to Solomon in 1 Chronicles 28:11–12?
options: They establish a prototype for perpetual presence before God
verseText: [He put in the hand of his son the plans of the porch of the temple, its buildings, its treasuries… its shows, its knives, its gold.]

text: In 1 Chronicles 12:2–9, the mention of Ishmaelite and other foreign warriors joining David reveals what strategic dynamic?
options: David’s kingdom‑building through inclusion of non‑Israelite contingents
verseText: [Among the Benjamites, from Machir, from among the Gadites… from the Manassites…] and Ishmaelite men of war joined David.

text: What theological motif is central to the 'Song of thanks' in 1 Chronicles 16:34–36?
options: God’s enduring steadfast love across generations
The architectural beauty of the temple
verseText: [O give thanks to the LORD, for he is good; for his steadfast love endures forever.]

text: How does the appointment of Shemaiah’s descendants as gatekeepers in 1 Chronicles 26:4–15 underscore temple theology?
options: It links physical thresholds with familial consecration
verseText: [The sons of Shemaiah… were in charge of the treasuries and the treasurers of the temple.]

text: What narrative purpose is served by the blessing on Obed‑Edom’s house in 1 Chronicles 13:13?
options: It demonstrates God’s favor when divine protocols are respected
verseText: [So David was afraid of God that day… and said, 'How can the ark of the Lord come to me?'] Yet the LORD blessed the house of Obed‑Edom.

text: How does the phrase 'did not seek him according to the rule' in 1 Chronicles 15:13 deepen our understanding of Levitical law?
options: It highlights the necessity of precise ritual observance for divine presence
It introduces a new Mosaic covenant
verseText: [Because you did not carry it the first time, the LORD our God broke out against us, because we did not seek him according to the rule.]

text: What editorial intent is suggested by the compilation of multiple psalms in 1 Chronicles 16:8–36?
options: To present David as the ideal worship leader through curated liturgy
verseText: [Oh give thanks to the LORD… and say, 'Save us, O God of our salvation; gather and rescue us from the nations.']

text: What does David’s reorganization of tribal leaders in 1 Chronicles 27:6–15 reveal about his governance style?
options: A systematic, merit‑based administration tied to tribal identity
A focus on religious over civic roles
verseText: [Over the Reubenites, Eliezer son of Zichri; Over the Gadites, Eliasaph son of Reuel… each with 1,000,000 men of valor.]

text: How does David’s purchase of Araunah’s threshing floor in 1 Chronicles 21:22–25 serve as a legal and theological precedent?
options: It establishes the principle of voluntary purchase rather than divine gift for sacred space
It creates a new war monopoly
verseText: [And David said to Araunah, 'No, but I will buy it from you… that the plague may be stayed from the people.']

text: What does listing Shemei and Geber as Benjaminite leaders in 1 Chronicles 12:1 illustrate about tribal politics?
options: The strategic alignment of key clan heads with David’s cause
A dissenting faction within David’s court
verseText: [From Benjamin… Shammah the Hararite, Jeiel the Meshullamite, Ismaiah… Shemei… Geber…]

text: How does the census narrative in 1 Chronicles 21:1–7 reflect Israel’s theological ambivalence toward numbering its people?
options: It portrays human counting as susceptible to sin without divine sanction
verseText: [Satan incited David to number Israel… so David said to Joab… the total was 1,100,000 men able to draw the sword.]

text: What critical function does placing genealogies at the start of 1 Chronicles serve in the book’s overall composition?
options: It roots Israel’s identity and Davidic legitimacy in ancestral memory
It fills out idle scribal pages
verseText: [These are the names of the people whom the LORD gave Abram… lists from Adam to Abraham.]

text: How does the injunction to 'praise his name with dancing' in 1 Chronicles 16:31–33 deepen our understanding of worship in David’s reign?
options: It integrates embodied celebration into covenantal praise
It restricts worship to the temple precinct
verseText: [Let the heavens be glad, and let the earth rejoice; and let them say among the nations, 'The LORD reigns!']

text: What does the brief genealogy of Jabez in 1 Chronicles 4:9–10 demonstrate about the Chronicler’s editorial focus?
options: Elevation of personal piety and prayer over mere lineage listing
verseText: [Jabez was more honorable than his brothers… and he called upon the God of Israel… 'Oh that you would bless me and enlarge my border!']

text: How does the parallel between David’s charge in 1 Chronicles 17 and his address in 28–29 function as a literary device?
options: It creates a covenantal frame emphasizing continuity and promise
It alternates priestly and royal speeches
It contrasts northern and southern tribes
verseText: [When your days are fulfilled… I will establish his throne forever.] / [Be strong and courageous; do not be afraid or discouraged.]

text: What does the depiction of God ‘preparing a dwelling place for his people’ in David’s final prayer (1 Chronicles 29:9–10) evoke from Israel’s earlier traditions?
options: Imagery of the divine sanctuary akin to Edenic fellowship
verseText: [And all the assembly blessed the LORD,… saying, 'Yours, O LORD, is the greatness and the power and the glory…' ]

text: What political‑theological statement is made by assigning each tribe a monthly service in 1 Chronicles 27?
options: Integration of tribal identity into centralized rule under David
Division of the kingdom into two states
verseText: [All these were in their divisions for the service of the king’s house, one month in a year…]

text: How does the Merarite assignment to noisemaking at the temple gates in 1 Chronicles 26:1–5 reflect symbolic theology?
options: It connects sound with sanctified boundary‑keeping
verseText: [David and the officials… made the sons of the Korahites and Merarites the gatekeepers of the thresholds.]

text: In 1 Chronicles 12:2–8, what strategic purpose do the non‑Israelite contingents serve in David’s campaign narrative?
options: They underscore divine endorsement through broadened coalition
verseText: [From Manasseh… from Zebulun… from Naphtali… and foreign warriors joined David.]

text: What typological significance do David’s temple plans in 1 Chronicles 28:11–12 hold for post‑exilic readers?
options: They symbolize the hope for restored divine presence
verseText: [He put in Solomon’s hand the plan of the porch of the temple and its buildings…]

text: How does the Chronicler’s portrayal of Saul’s failures in contrast to David’s Levitical centralization advance the book’s theology?
options: By validating David as God’s rightful anointed through proper worship order
verseText: [Only Levites may carry the ark…] / [Satan incited David to number Israel.]

text: What is the significance of the communal feast described at the dedication in 1 Chronicles 29:22–23?
options: It enacts covenant renewal through shared celebration
It marks the end of military campaigns
It inaugurates a new tax cycle
verseText: [They ate and drank… and made great sacrifices… for God gladdened them with the joy of their king.]
